html.html: HyperText Markup Language (HTML) is the essential building block of the web. It is used to structure content using elements enclosed in tags. HTML tells the browser what each piece of content represents: is it a heading, a paragraph, a link, or an image? It acts as the semantic backbone of any webpage.
html.html tags: HTML elements are defined by tags. Common tags include h1 through h6 for hierarchical headings, p for standard paragraphs of text, a for hyperlinks (the H in HTML), img for embedding images, and structural tags like div and span for grouping content and applying styling.
html.html structure: A proper HTML document structure includes DOCTYPE html, html, head (metadata, title, links), and body (visible content). The head contains metadata and the body contains all visible page content.
html.html headings: Headings are defined using h1 through h6 tags, with h1 being the largest and most important for SEO and accessibility. Use them in hierarchical order for proper document structure.
html.html paragraphs: The p tag defines a paragraph of text with automatic spacing before and after. Use paragraphs to organize and separate blocks of text content.
html.html links: The a tag creates hyperlinks using the href attribute to specify the destination URL. Links can point to external websites, pages within your site, or sections via ID anchors.
html.html images: The img tag embeds images with src (source) and alt (alternative text) attributes. The alt text is crucial for accessibility and SEO, describing the image content.
html.html attributes: Attributes provide additional information about HTML elements, such as id, class, href, src, style, and data attributes. Attributes are key-value pairs that modify element behavior.
html.html id: The id attribute uniquely identifies an element within a page, used for styling and JavaScript targeting. Each ID should be unique within a page.
html.html class: The class attribute assigns one or more classes to elements for CSS styling and grouping similar elements. Multiple classes can be applied to a single element.
html.html lists: HTML supports ordered lists, unordered lists, and description lists, each containing list items or descriptions. Lists organize related content in a structured format.
html.html ordered list: The ordered list creates numbered lists. Use ordered lists when sequence or priority matters, like steps in a process or rankings.
html.html unordered list: The unordered list creates bulleted lists. Use unordered lists for collections of items without a specific order or hierarchy.
html.html tables: Tables organize data in rows and columns using table, tr (rows), td (cells), and th (headers). Tables are ideal for displaying structured data like schedules or datasets.
html.html forms: The form element collects user input through various input types and submission methods. Forms are essential for user interaction, contact submissions, and data collection.
html.html form input: Input types include text, password, email, number, date, checkbox, radio, submit, and file. Different input types provide appropriate keyboards and validation on mobile devices.
html.html form textarea: The textarea element creates a multi-line text input field. Use textarea for longer text entries like messages or comments.
html.html form select: The select element creates a dropdown list with option elements. Dropdowns save space and help users choose from predefined options.
html.html form label: The label element associates text with form inputs for better accessibility and usability. Labels increase clickable area on mobile and help screen readers.
html.html form button: The button element creates clickable buttons with customizable types: submit, reset, or button. Buttons trigger actions or submit form data.
html.html semantic: Semantic HTML uses meaningful tags like header, nav, main, article, section, footer to clearly describe content structure. Semantic HTML improves accessibility and SEO.
html.html header: The header element represents introductory content or top navigation of a page or section. Headers typically contain site branding and main navigation.
html.html nav: The nav element contains navigation links, typically within the header or footer. Use nav for primary navigation menus and link collections.
html.html main: The main element specifies the main content of the page, used once per page. All primary page content should be wrapped in the main element.
html.html article: The article element represents self-contained content like blog posts or news items. Articles can be independently distributed or reused.
html.html section: The section element groups related content and is used to organize page structure. Sections help thematically divide content on a page.
html.html aside: The aside element contains supplementary content like sidebars or related links. Use aside for content tangentially related to the main content.
html.html footer: The footer element contains footer information like copyright, links, or contact details. Footers typically appear at the bottom of pages or sections.
html.html div: The div element is a generic container for grouping content and applying styles without semantic meaning. Use divs when no other semantic element fits.
html.html span: The span element is an inline container for styling portions of text without line breaks. Span allows styling specific text while keeping it inline.
html.html strong: The strong element emphasizes text with strong importance, conveying urgency or criticality. Strong text indicates semantic importance, not just visual styling.
html.html em: The em element emphasizes text with stress, indicating emphasis or a change in tone. Em provides semantic emphasis for screen readers and search engines.
html.html br: The br element creates a line break within text or content. Use br sparingly; CSS is often better for layout control.
html.html hr: The hr element creates a horizontal line separator. Use hr to thematically separate sections of content.
html.html meta: The meta tag provides metadata like character set, viewport settings, and descriptions. Meta tags help browsers and search engines understand your page.
html.html charset: The charset attribute specifies character encoding, typically UTF-8 for proper text rendering. UTF-8 supports all languages and special characters.
html.html viewport: The viewport meta tag controls layout on mobile browsers and enables responsive design. Viewport settings ensure proper scaling on different devices.
html.html audio: The audio element embeds audio files with controls for playback. Audio elements support multiple file formats for browser compatibility.
html.html video: The video element embeds video files with controls, poster image, and source management. Videos can include fallback content for unsupported browsers.
html.html canvas: The canvas element creates a drawable surface for graphics via JavaScript. Canvas enables game development, animations, and dynamic graphics.
html.html svg: The svg element embeds scalable vector graphics for icons and illustrations. SVG graphics scale perfectly and can be styled with CSS.
html.html iframe: The iframe element embeds external web pages or documents within a page. Iframes allow embedding content from other sources.
html.html comments: HTML comments are hidden from browsers and useful for documentation. Comments are useful for leaving notes in your code.
html.html entities: HTML entities encode special characters like less-than, greater-than, ampersand, and non-breaking space. Entities ensure special characters display correctly.
html.html css link: CSS stylesheets are linked in the head using link tag with rel stylesheet and href attributes. External stylesheets keep HTML and CSS separated.
html.html javascript: JavaScript is embedded using script tags within the document or linked externally. Scripts can be placed in the head or at the end of the body.
html.html accessibility: Semantic HTML, alt attributes, labels, and ARIA attributes improve accessibility for assistive technologies. Accessibility ensures your site works for everyone.
html.html aria: ARIA (Accessible Rich Internet Applications) attributes enhance accessibility for screen readers. ARIA provides additional context for complex components.
html.html seo: SEO best practices include semantic HTML, proper heading hierarchy, meta descriptions, and keyword-rich content. Good SEO helps search engines index your content.
html.html responsive: Responsive HTML uses the viewport meta tag and flexible structures to adapt to different screen sizes. Responsive design ensures usability across all devices.
html.html data attributes: Data attributes store custom data on elements for use with CSS and JavaScript. Data attributes let you associate metadata with HTML elements.
html.html doctype: The DOCTYPE html declaration tells the browser this is an HTML5 document. Doctype must be the first line of any HTML document.
html.html validation: HTML validation ensures code follows standards and best practices using online validators. Valid HTML improves compatibility and reduces bugs.
html.html block elements: Block elements take full width and create new lines. Block elements start on a new line and take up available horizontal space.
html.html inline elements: Inline elements only take necessary width without line breaks. Inline elements flow within text and don't break lines.
html.html inline block: Inline-block elements combine inline and block properties through CSS. This allows elements to sit side-by-side like inline but with block properties like width and height.

css.css: Cascading Style Sheets (CSS) is the language used for describing the presentation of a document written in HTML. CSS is responsible for the visual aesthetics—controlling the **layout**, **colors**, **fonts**, **spacing**, and overall responsiveness of a website. It separates the document's presentation from its content.
css.css properties: CSS properties define the style attributes applied to selected elements. Common properties include color, background-color, font-size, margin, padding, border, width, height, and display.
css.css static positioning: Static positioning is the default. Elements flow normally in the document and top/right/bottom/left properties have no effect.
css.css relative positioning: Relative positioning offsets an element from its normal position, but the element still takes up space in the document flow.
css.css absolute positioning: Absolute positioning removes an element from the document flow and positions it relative to the nearest positioned ancestor or the viewport.
css.css fixed positioning: Fixed positioning removes an element from the flow and positions it relative to the viewport, keeping it in place when scrolling.
css.css sticky positioning: Sticky positioning acts like relative until the element reaches a specified threshold, then acts like fixed.
css.css flexbox: CSS Flexbox (Flexible Box Layout) is a one-dimensional layout model designed for distributing space and aligning items. Use `display: flex`, `justify-content`, `align-items`, `flex-direction`, and `flex-wrap` to create flexible layouts.
css.css shadows:
Box and text shadows add depth. Use `box-shadow` for elements and `text-shadow` for text.
box-shadow: 0 4px 8px rgba(0,0,0,0.2);
text-shadow: 2px 2px 4px black;
css.css transitions:
Transitions smoothly animate CSS property changes. Use `transition`, `transition-duration`, `transition-timing-function`, and `transition-delay`.
transition: background-color 0.3s ease;
transition: all 0.5s linear;
css.css opacity:
Opacity controls element transparency from 0 (fully transparent) to 1 (fully opaque).
opacity: 0.5;
opacity: 0;
css.css z-index: The `z-index` property controls stacking order of positioned elements. Higher values appear on top. Requires `position` to be set.
css.css pseudo-elements:
Pseudo-elements style specific parts of elements: `::before`, `::after`, `::first-line`, `::first-letter`, `::selection`.
p::before { content: "→"; }
p::first-line { font-weight: bold; }
css.css hover: The `:hover` pseudo-class styles elements when the mouse hovers over them.
css.css active: The `:active` pseudo-class styles elements while they are being clicked.
css.css focus: The `:focus` pseudo-class styles form elements when they receive keyboard focus.
css.css visited: The `:visited` pseudo-class styles links that have been previously visited by the user.
css.css nth-child: The `:nth-child()` pseudo-class selects elements based on position. Use `2n` for even, `2n+1` for odd, or specific numbers.
css.css nth-of-type: The `:nth-of-type()` pseudo-class selects elements of a specific type based on position.
css.css first-child: The `:first-child` pseudo-class selects the first child element regardless of type.
css.css last-child: The `:last-child` pseudo-class selects the last child element.
css.css not selector: The `:not()` pseudo-class selects elements that do not match a selector.
css.css responsive design: Responsive design makes websites adaptable to different screen sizes using flexible layouts, media queries, and flexible images.
css.css mobile first: Mobile-first approach starts with mobile styles and adds styles for larger screens using min-width media queries.
css.css units: CSS supports various units: `px` (pixels), `em` (relative to font-size), `rem` (relative to root font-size), `%` (percentage), `vw`/`vh` (viewport width/height), `vmin`/`vmax`.
css.css font-size: Font size controls text size. Use absolute units (`px`), relative units (`em`, `rem`), or percentages. `1em` equals the element's font-size; `1rem` equals the root element's font-size.
css.css width height: Width and height properties set element dimensions. Can be `px`, `em`, `%`, or `auto`. The `max-width` and `min-width` properties constrain dimensions.
css.css min-width max-width: Min-width sets minimum width; max-width sets maximum width. Useful for responsive design and preventing overflow.
css.css aspect ratio: The `aspect-ratio` property maintains a specific width-to-height ratio, useful for images and videos.
css.css word-break: The `word-break` property controls how words break: `normal`, `break-all`, `keep-all`.
css.css text-overflow: The `text-overflow` property handles overflow text: `clip`, `ellipsis`. Usually paired with `white-space: nowrap` and `overflow: hidden`.
css.css vertical-align: The `vertical-align` property aligns inline or inline-block elements vertically. Works with `baseline`, `top`, `middle`, `bottom`.
css.css list style: List properties: `list-style-type` (disc, circle, square, decimal), `list-style-image`, `list-style-position`, or shorthand `list-style`.
css.css cursor: The `cursor` property changes the mouse pointer style: `pointer`, `default`, `text`, `move`, `wait`, `not-allowed`, etc.
css.css backdrop-filter: The `backdrop-filter` property applies effects to content behind an element, creating frosted glass effects.
css.css mix-blend-mode: The `mix-blend-mode` property blends an element with its background using modes like `multiply`, `screen`, `overlay`, `lighten`, `darken`.
css.css clip-path:
The `clip-path` property creates clipping regions using shapes like `circle()`, `ellipse()`, `polygon()`, `inset()`.
clip-path: circle(50%);
clip-path: polygon(0% 0%, 100% 0%, 100% 100%);
css.css object-fit: The `object-fit` property controls how images fill containers: `fill`, `contain`, `cover`, `scale-down`.
css.css object-position: The `object-position` property specifies image position within its container.
css.css specificity: CSS specificity determines which rule applies when multiple selectors target the same element. Specificity increases with inline styles, IDs, classes, and elements.
css.css inheritance: Some CSS properties automatically inherit from parent elements (color, font). Others do not (margin, padding). Use `inherit` to force inheritance or `initial` to reset.
css.css cascade: CSS cascade applies styles based on source order, specificity, and importance. Later rules override earlier ones if specificity is equal.
css.css important: The `!important` flag increases specificity, overriding normal cascade rules. Use sparingly as it creates maintenance issues.
css.css variables:
CSS custom properties (variables) store reusable values defined with `--name` and accessed with `var(--name)`.
:root { --primary-color: #3498db; }
button { background: var(--primary-color); }
css.css calc: The `calc()` function performs calculations within CSS, mixing units like `width: calc(100% - 20px)`.
css.css before after: The `::before` and `::after` pseudo-elements insert content before/after elements using the `content` property.
css.css content: The `content` property specifies what to generate in `::before` and `::after` pseudo-elements. Use text, images, counters, or `attr()`.
css.css counters: CSS counters track occurrences using `counter-reset`, `counter-increment`, and `counter()` in `content`.
css.css outline: The `outline` property draws a line around elements, outside the border. Useful for focus states and doesn't affect layout.
css.css box-shadow: Box shadows create layered shadows: `box-shadow: offset-x offset-y blur-radius spread-radius color`.
css.css gradient:
CSS gradients create smooth color transitions using `linear-gradient()`, `radial-gradient()`, `conic-gradient()`.
background: linear-gradient(to right, red, blue);
background: radial-gradient(circle, yellow 0%, blue 100%);
css.css linear-gradient: Linear gradients transition colors in a specific direction using `to top`, `to right`, or angle values.
css.css radial-gradient: Radial gradients emanate from a center point, useful for spotlight or vignette effects.
css.css conic-gradient: Conic gradients rotate colors around a center point, useful for pie charts or color wheels.
css.css repeating-gradient: Repeating gradients repeat color stops infinitely, creating stripe patterns.
css.css vendor prefixes: Vendor prefixes like `-webkit-`, `-moz-`, `-ms-` enable experimental CSS features in specific browsers.
css.css float: The `float` property removes elements from normal flow, positioning them left or right. Modern layouts prefer flexbox/grid.
css.css clear: The `clear` property prevents elements from wrapping around floated elements: `left`, `right`, `both`.
css.css clearfix: Clearfix is a technique to contain floated elements, often using `::after` pseudo-element with `clear: both`.
css.css table display: CSS can style tables: `display: table`, `display: table-row`, `display: table-cell` for table-like layouts.
css.css form styling: Style form elements using border, padding, background, focus states, and placeholder pseudo-element.
css.css button styling: Style buttons with background, color, border, padding, cursor, hover, and active states.
css.css input styling: Style input fields with border, padding, focus effects, and `::placeholder` for placeholder styling.
css.css select styling: Style select dropdowns (limited due to browser default). Use appearance: none to customize with background-image.
css.css checkbox radio: Style checkboxes and radio buttons using `accent-color` or custom styling with pseudo-elements.
css.css placeholder: The `::placeholder` pseudo-element styles placeholder text in form inputs.
css.css appearance: The `appearance` property removes default browser styling: `appearance: none` to customize form elements.
css.css print styles: Use `@media print` to define styles for printed documents, hiding elements or adjusting layout.
css.css page break: Control page breaks with `page-break-before`, `page-break-after`, `page-break-inside` for print.
css.css justify-content: Flexbox/Grid property aligning items along main axis: `flex-start`, `center`, `flex-end`, `space-between`, `space-around`, `space-evenly`.
css.css align-items: Flexbox/Grid property aligning items along cross axis: `stretch`, `flex-start`, `center`, `flex-end`, `baseline`.
css.css align-content: Grid property controlling alignment of grid rows along vertical axis.
css.css align-self: Property for individual flex/grid items to override `align-items`.
css.css flex-grow: Flex item property controlling how much the item grows relative to available space.
css.css flex-shrink: Flex item property controlling how much the item shrinks relative to available space.
css.css flex-basis: Flex item property setting initial main size before free space distribution.
css.css gap: Sets spacing between flex/grid items, cleaner than margin workarounds.
css.css text-orientation: The `text-orientation` property rotates characters in vertical writing modes.
css.css direction: The `direction` property sets text direction: `ltr` (left-to-right) or `rtl` (right-to-left).
css.css unicode-bidi: The `unicode-bidi` property controls bidirectional text rendering.

javascript.javascript: JavaScript (JS) is a high-level, interpreted programming language that is one of the core technologies of the World Wide Web. It enables **interactive** and dynamic features on websites, such as handling user input, manipulating the Document Object Model (DOM), and managing asynchronous operations like network requests. It's the engine that brings web applications to life.
javascript.js variables: JavaScript variables store data values. Use `const` (preferred, immutable reference), `let` (block-scoped), or `var` (function-scoped, avoid). Declare with assignment: `const name = 'Alice';`
javascript.js data types: JavaScript supports primitives: `string`, `number`, `boolean`, `null`, `undefined`, `symbol`, `bigint`. Complex types include `object` and `array`. Use `typeof` to check types.
javascript.js functions:
Functions in JavaScript are fundamental building blocks. They are **reusable blocks of code** that perform a specific task or calculate a value. They can accept inputs (parameters) and can return an output. Defining functions with the `function` keyword or as **arrow functions** (`=>`) helps modularize code and prevents repetition.
function greet(name) { return `Hello, ${name}`; }
const add = (a, b) => a + b;
javascript.js arrow functions:
Arrow functions provide concise syntax and lexical `this` binding. Syntax: `(params) => expression` or `(params) => { statements }`.
const square = x => x * x;
const multiply = (a, b) => a * b;
javascript.js arrays:
Arrays store multiple values in a single variable. Access via zero-based indexing. Methods include `push()`, `pop()`, `map()`, `filter()`, `reduce()`.
const nums = [1, 2, 3];
const doubled = nums.map(n => n * 2);
javascript.js strings: Strings are sequences of characters. Use template literals for interpolation: `` `Hello ${name}` ``. Methods include `substring()`, `slice()`, `toUpperCase()`, `split()`.
javascript.js destructuring:
Destructuring extracts values from arrays or properties from objects into distinct variables.
const [a, b] = [1, 2];
const { name, age } = { name: 'Alice', age: 25 };
javascript.js ternary operator:
The ternary operator provides a shorthand for if-else: `condition ? trueValue : falseValue`.
const status = age >= 18 ? 'Adult' : 'Minor';
javascript.js loops:
Loops repeat code: `for` (iterate over range), `while` (condition-based), `do-while`, `for...of` (iterate values), `for...in` (iterate keys).
for (let i = 0; i < 5; i++) console.log(i);
for (const item of array) console.log(item);
javascript.js for loop: The `for` loop repeats code a specific number of times with initialization, condition, and increment.
javascript.js while loop: The `while` loop repeats as long as a condition is true.
javascript.js do while loop: The `do-while` loop executes at least once, then repeats if the condition is true.
javascript.js for...of loop: The `for...of` loop iterates over values in iterable objects like arrays and strings.
javascript.js for...in loop: The `for...in` loop iterates over enumerable property keys in objects and arrays.
javascript.js break continue: The `break` statement exits a loop; `continue` skips to the next iteration.
javascript.js map method:
The `map()` method creates a new array by applying a function to each element.
const nums = [1, 2, 3];
const squared = nums.map(n => n * n);
javascript.js filter method:
The `filter()` method creates a new array with elements that satisfy a condition.
const nums = [1, 2, 3, 4];
const evens = nums.filter(n => n % 2 === 0);
javascript.js reduce method:
The `reduce()` method applies a function cumulatively to reduce an array to a single value.
const nums = [1, 2, 3, 4];
const sum = nums.reduce((acc, n) => acc + n, 0);
javascript.js find method:
The `find()` method returns the first element matching a condition.
const nums = [1, 2, 3];
const first = nums.find(n => n > 1);
javascript.js foreach method: The `forEach()` method executes a function for each array element, with no return value.
javascript.js some every: `some()` checks if at least one element matches a condition; `every()` checks if all elements match.
javascript.js includes: The `includes()` method checks if an array or string contains a specific value.
javascript.js indexOf: The `indexOf()` method returns the index of the first occurrence of a value, or -1 if not found.
javascript.js slice: The `slice()` method returns a shallow copy of a portion of an array or string without modifying the original.
javascript.js splice: The `splice()` method changes array contents by adding/removing elements.
javascript.js sort: The `sort()` method sorts array elements in place. Pass a comparator function for custom sorting.
javascript.js reverse: The `reverse()` method reverses array elements in place.
javascript.js concat: The `concat()` method combines arrays or strings without modifying the originals.
javascript.js join: The `join()` method combines array elements into a string with a separator.
javascript.js split: The `split()` method splits a string into an array based on a separator.
javascript.js substring: The `substring()` method extracts characters between two indices (similar to `slice()`).
javascript.js trim: The `trim()` method removes whitespace from both ends of a string.
javascript.js replace: The `replace()` method replaces the first match of a pattern in a string.
javascript.js replaceall: The `replaceAll()` method replaces all occurrences of a pattern in a string.
javascript.js startswith endswith: `startsWith()` checks if a string begins with characters; `endsWith()` checks the end.
javascript.js includes string: The `includes()` method checks if a string contains a substring.
javascript.js touppercase tolowercase: `toUpperCase()` converts to uppercase; `toLowerCase()` converts to lowercase.
javascript.js charat: The `charAt()` method returns the character at a specified index.
javascript.js charcodeat: The `charCodeAt()` method returns the Unicode code point of a character.
javascript.js dom: The DOM (Document Object Model) is a programming interface for HTML documents. JavaScript manipulates DOM elements to create dynamic content.
javascript.js document object: The `document` object represents the HTML page and provides methods to access and modify elements.
javascript.js getelementbyid: The `getElementById()` method selects an element by its `id` attribute.
javascript.js getelementsbyclassname: The `getElementsByClassName()` method selects all elements with a specific class (returns live collection).
javascript.js getelementsbytagname: The `getElementsByTagName()` method selects all elements with a specific tag name.
javascript.js queryselector: The `querySelector()` method selects the first element matching a CSS selector.
javascript.js queryselectorall: The `querySelectorAll()` method selects all elements matching a CSS selector (returns NodeList).
javascript.js innerhtml: The `innerHTML` property gets or sets the HTML content inside an element.
javascript.js textcontent: The `textContent` property gets or sets the text content of an element.
javascript.js createelement: The `createElement()` method creates a new HTML element in memory.
javascript.js appendchild: The `appendChild()` method adds a child element to the end of a parent element.
javascript.js removechild: The `removeChild()` method removes a specified child element.
javascript.js insertbefore: The `insertBefore()` method inserts an element before a specified element.
javascript.js setattribute: The `setAttribute()` method adds or updates an attribute on an element.
javascript.js removeattribute: The `removeAttribute()` method removes an attribute from an element.
javascript.js getattribute: The `getAttribute()` method retrieves the value of an attribute.
javascript.js addeventlistener: The `addEventListener()` method registers an event handler for a specific event on an element.
javascript.js events: Events are user interactions or system occurrences. Common events: `click`, `mouseover`, `keydown`, `submit`, `change`, `load`.
javascript.js click event: The `click` event fires when an element is clicked.
javascript.js mouseover mouseout: `mouseover` fires when mouse enters an element; `mouseout` fires when it leaves.
javascript.js keydown keyup: `keydown` fires when a key is pressed; `keyup` fires when released.
javascript.js submit event: The `submit` event fires when a form is submitted.
javascript.js change event: The `change` event fires when form input value changes and loses focus.
javascript.js focus blur: `focus` fires when an element receives focus; `blur` fires when it loses focus.
javascript.js preventdefault: The `preventDefault()` method cancels an event's default action.
javascript.js stoppropagation: The `stopPropagation()` method prevents event bubbling up the DOM tree.
javascript.js event bubbling: Event bubbling causes events to propagate up the DOM tree from child to parent elements.
javascript.js event capturing: Event capturing causes events to propagate down the DOM tree from parent to child elements.
javascript.js event delegation: Event delegation uses a single event listener on a parent to handle events from multiple children.
javascript.js callbacks: Callbacks are functions passed as arguments to other functions, executed when a specific condition occurs.
javascript.js then catch: The `then()` method handles promise resolution; `catch()` handles rejection. Chain multiple `.then()` calls.
javascript.js fetch api: The `fetch()` function retrieves data from URLs and returns a promise.
javascript.js json: JSON (JavaScript Object Notation) is a text format for data. Use `JSON.parse()` to convert strings to objects, `JSON.stringify()` for the reverse.
javascript.js localstorage: Local storage persists key-value data in the browser. Methods: `setItem()`, `getItem()`, `removeItem()`, `clear()`.
javascript.js sessionstorage: Session storage is like local storage but clears when the browser session ends.
javascript.js cookies: Cookies store small amounts of data on the client, sent with HTTP requests. Access via `document.cookie`.
javascript.js regex:
Regular expressions are patterns for matching and manipulating strings. Create with `/pattern/flags` or `new RegExp()`.
const regex = /hello/i;
const matches = 'Hello world'.match(regex);
javascript.js match: The `match()` method searches a string for matches against a regex.
javascript.js test: The `test()` method checks if a regex matches a string, returning true or false.
javascript.js search: The `search()` method returns the index of the first regex match in a string.
javascript.js exec: The `exec()` method executes a regex on a string and returns match details.
javascript.js typeof: The `typeof` operator returns the data type of a value as a string.
javascript.js instanceof: The `instanceof` operator checks if an object is an instance of a class.
javascript.js this: The `this` keyword refers to the object the function belongs to. Its value depends on how the function is called.
javascript.js call apply bind: `call()` and `apply()` invoke a function with a specific `this` value. `bind()` creates a new function with fixed `this`.
javascript.js closures: Closures are functions that access variables from their enclosing scope, even after the outer function returns.
javascript.js scope: Scope determines variable visibility. Types: global, function, block (with `let`/`const`).
javascript.js hoisting: Hoisting moves variable declarations to the top of their scope. `var` is hoisted; `let`/`const` are not (temporal dead zone).
javascript.js this binding: The value of `this` depends on how a function is called: method (object), function (global), arrow (lexical), or explicit (call/apply/bind).
javascript.js prototype: Prototypes enable inheritance by allowing objects to inherit properties from other objects.
javascript.js static methods: Static methods belong to the class itself, not instances, defined with `static` keyword.
javascript.js getter setter: Getters and setters define custom get/set behavior for properties using `get` and `set` keywords.
javascript.js extends: The `extends` keyword enables class inheritance, inheriting properties and methods from parent classes.
javascript.js super: The `super` keyword calls parent class methods and the parent constructor.
javascript.js instanceof class: The `instanceof` operator checks if an object is an instance of a class.
javascript.js array destructuring: Array destructuring extracts multiple values from arrays into separate variables.
javascript.js object destructuring: Object destructuring extracts properties from objects into separate variables with optional renaming.
javascript.js rest parameters: Rest parameters (`...`) capture remaining arguments into an array in function parameters.
javascript.js default parameters: Default parameters provide fallback values if arguments are not provided.
javascript.js object shorthand: Object shorthand allows concise property definitions: `{ name }` instead of `{ name: name }`.
javascript.js computed properties: Computed property names use bracket notation for dynamic property names in objects.
javascript.js for await of: The `for await...of` loop iterates over async iterables, awaiting each value.
javascript.js generator: Generators are functions that can pause and resume using `function*` and `yield`.
javascript.js yield: The `yield` keyword pauses a generator function and returns a value.
javascript.js map object: Maps store key-value pairs like objects but allow any value as a key, not just strings.
javascript.js set object: Sets store unique values, eliminating duplicates. Methods: `add()`, `delete()`, `has()`, `clear()`.
javascript.js weakmap weakset: WeakMaps and WeakSets hold weak references, allowing garbage collection of unused objects.
javascript.js error handling: JavaScript error types: `Error`, `SyntaxError`, `ReferenceError`, `TypeError`, `RangeError`. Use `try...catch` for handling.
javascript.js try catch finally: Try-catch-finally blocks handle errors: `try` runs code, `catch` handles errors, `finally` runs regardless.
javascript.js throw: The `throw` statement triggers a custom error or exception.
javascript.js typeof operator: The `typeof` operator returns a string indicating the type of a value.
javascript.js isnan isnull: `isNaN()` checks if a value is NaN; Use strict equality `=== null` to check for null.
javascript.js undefined vs null: `undefined` means a variable has no value assigned; `null` is explicitly set for no value.
javascript.js boolean conversion: Values convert to boolean: falsy (`false`, `0`, `''`, `null`, `undefined`, `NaN`); truthy (everything else).
javascript.js date object: The `Date` object handles dates and times. Methods: `getFullYear()`, `getMonth()`, `getDate()`, `getTime()`, `toISOString()`.
javascript.js timeout interval: `setTimeout()` executes code after a delay; `setInterval()` executes code repeatedly at intervals. Both return IDs for clearing.
javascript.js strict mode: `'use strict';` enforces stricter parsing and error handling, preventing unreliable features.
javascript.js modules: Modules encapsulate code using `export` and `import`. Supports ES6 modules (`.mjs` or type: 'module') and CommonJS (`require()`, `module.exports`).
javascript.js export import: `export` exposes functions/variables; `import` brings them into another module.
javascript.js module pattern: The Module Pattern uses closures and IIFEs to create private variables and public methods.
javascript.js performance: Improve performance with event delegation, debouncing, throttling, lazy loading, and minimizing DOM manipulations.
javascript.js debounce throttle: Debounce delays function execution until a delay passes. Throttle limits execution frequency.
javascript.js accessibility: Improve JavaScript accessibility using semantic HTML, ARIA attributes, keyboard navigation, and screen reader compatibility.

python.python: Python is a powerful, high-level, interpreted programming language valued for its readability and simple syntax. It is versatile, widely used in web development (Django/Flask), data science, machine learning, automation, and scripting. Its extensive standard library and active community make it suitable for almost any task.
python.python variables:
Variables in Python are used to store data values such as numbers, text, or complex objects. They are created simply by assigning a value with the `=` operator, without prior declaration. Python is dynamically typed, meaning the type is inferred at runtime.
# Example variables
age = 25
name = 'Alice'
is_active = True
print(age, name, is_active)

Python provides several built-in data types: integers (`int`), floating-point numbers (`float`), and strings (`str`). More complex types include lists, tuples, dictionaries, and booleans.
# Data types
num = 42          # int
pi = 3.14         # float
text = 'Hello'    # str

point = (2, 3)    # tuple

python.python loops:
Loops allow repeated execution of code blocks. The `for` loop iterates over sequences, while the `while` loop runs as long as a condition remains true.
# For loop
for i in range(3):
    print(i)

count = 0
while count < 3:
    print(count)
    count += 1

Functions group instructions into reusable units, defined with the `def` keyword.
# Function example

A list is an ordered, mutable collection in Python.
# List example
my_list = [1, 2, 3, 'hello']
print(my_list[0])
my_list.append(4)
print(my_list)
python.python dictionary:
A dictionary stores data as key-value pairs.
# Dictionary example
person = {'name': 'Alice', 'age': 30}
print(person['name'])
print(person.get('age'))
python.python tuple:
A tuple is an ordered, immutable collection. Once created, its elements cannot be changed.
# Tuple example
coords = (10, 20, 30)
print(coords[0])
print(len(coords))
python.python set:
A set is an unordered collection of unique elements.
# Set example
unique_nums = {1, 2, 3, 3}
print(unique_nums)
unique_nums.add(4)
python.python string:

# String example
text = 'Hello World'
print(text.lower())

except ZeroDivisionError:

finally:

The `for` loop iterates over sequences or iterables.
# For loop example
fruits = ['apple', 'banana', 'cherry']
for fruit in fruits:
    print(fruit)
python.python while loop:
The `while` loop runs as long as a condition is true.
# While loop example
n = 1
while n <= 3:

    n += 1

List comprehensions provide a concise way to create lists based on existing sequences.

squares = [x**2 for x in range(5)]

python.python lambda:
Lambda functions are anonymous, single-expression functions defined with the `lambda` keyword.

square = lambda x: x**2
print(square(5))

The `map()` function applies a function to every item in an iterable.
# Map example
nums = [1, 2, 3]

print(squared)

The `filter()` function filters items from an iterable based on a condition.
# Filter example
nums = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]
evens = list(filter(lambda x: x % 2 == 0, nums))
print(evens)

# Reduce example
from functools import reduce
nums = [1, 2, 3, 4]
product = reduce(lambda x, y: x * y, nums)
print(product)
python.python file handling:
File handling involves opening, reading, writing, and closing files.
# File handling
with open('file.txt', 'r') as f:
    content = f.read()
    print(content)
python.python modules:
Modules are files containing Python code that can be imported and reused.
# Import example
import math
print(math.sqrt(16))
from math import pi
print(pi)
python.python numpy:
NumPy is a library for numerical computing with arrays and matrices.
# NumPy example
import numpy as np
arr = np.array([1, 2, 3])
print(arr.mean())
python.python pandas:
Pandas is a library for data manipulation using DataFrames.
# Pandas example

df = pd.DataFrame({'name': ['Alice', 'Bob'], 'age': [25, 30]})
print(df)
python.python slicing:
Slicing extracts portions of sequences using the `[start:stop:step]` syntax.
# Slicing example
text = 'Python'
print(text[0:3])
print(text[::-1])
python.python enumerate:
The `enumerate()` function returns both index and value from an iterable.
# Enumerate example
fruits = ['apple', 'banana']
for idx, fruit in enumerate(fruits):

The `zip()` function pairs elements from multiple iterables.

assert x > 0, 'x must be positive'

# *args and **kwargs

func(1, 2, name='Alice', age=30)

String formatting methods include f-strings, `.format()`, and `%` operator.
# F-string

print(f'Hello, {name}!')

Regular expressions pattern match strings using the `re` module.

python.python datetime:
The `datetime` module handles dates, times, and durations.

now = datetime.now()
print(now)

JSON handling uses the `json` module to parse and serialize data.

print(data['name'])

sql.sql: SQL (Structured Query Language) is a powerful language used for managing and manipulating relational databases. It allows you to perform operations such as querying data, inserting new records, updating existing data, and deleting records. SQL is essential for working with databases in data science and web development.
sql.sql select:
The `SELECT` statement is used to query data from a database. It allows you to specify which columns to retrieve and from which table.
SELECT name, age FROM users;
sql.sql where:
The `WHERE` clause is used to filter records based on specified conditions.
SELECT * FROM users WHERE age > 30;
sql.sql join:
The `JOIN` clause combines rows from two or more tables based on a related column.
SELECT orders.id, customers.name FROM orders
JOIN customers ON orders.customer_id = customers.id;
sql.sql left join:
The `LEFT JOIN` returns all rows from the left table and matching rows from the right table.
SELECT users.name, orders.id FROM users
LEFT JOIN orders ON users.id = orders.user_id;
sql.sql right join:
The `RIGHT JOIN` returns all rows from the right table and matching rows from the left table.
SELECT users.name, orders.id FROM users
RIGHT JOIN orders ON users.id = orders.user_id;
sql.sql inner join:
The `INNER JOIN` returns only matching rows from both tables.
SELECT users.name, orders.id FROM users
INNER JOIN orders ON users.id = orders.user_id;
sql.sql insert:
The `INSERT` statement adds new records to a table.
INSERT INTO users (name, age) VALUES ('Alice', 30);
sql.sql update:
The `UPDATE` statement modifies existing records in a table.
UPDATE users SET age = 31 WHERE name = 'Alice';
sql.sql delete:
The `DELETE` statement removes records from a table.
DELETE FROM users WHERE age < 18;
sql.sql group by:
The `GROUP BY` clause groups rows sharing a property so aggregates can be applied.
SELECT department, COUNT(*) FROM employees GROUP BY department;
sql.sql order by:
The `ORDER BY` clause sorts results in ascending or descending order.
SELECT * FROM users ORDER BY age DESC;
sql.sql aggregate functions:
Aggregate functions like `COUNT()`, `SUM()`, `AVG()`, `MAX()`, and `MIN()` perform calculations on data.
SELECT COUNT(*), AVG(age) FROM users;
sql.sql create table:
The `CREATE TABLE` statement creates a new table with specified columns and data types (DDL).
CREATE TABLE users (
  id INT PRIMARY KEY,
  name VARCHAR(100),
  age INT
);
sql.sql alter table:
The `ALTER TABLE` statement modifies table structure by adding, removing, or modifying columns (DDL).
ALTER TABLE users ADD COLUMN email VARCHAR(100);
sql.sql drop table:
The `DROP TABLE` statement deletes an entire table and its data (DDL).
DROP TABLE users;
sql.sql truncate:
The `TRUNCATE` statement removes all records from a table but keeps the structure (DDL).
TRUNCATE TABLE users;
sql.sql grant:
The `GRANT` statement assigns permissions to users for database objects (DCL).
GRANT SELECT, INSERT ON users TO 'user1'@'localhost';
sql.sql revoke:
The `REVOKE` statement removes permissions from users (DCL).
REVOKE INSERT ON users FROM 'user1'@'localhost';
sql.sql commit:
The `COMMIT` statement saves all changes made in the current transaction (TCL).
INSERT INTO users (name) VALUES ('Bob');
COMMIT;
sql.sql rollback:
The `ROLLBACK` statement undoes all changes made in the current transaction (TCL).
DELETE FROM users;
ROLLBACK;
sql.sql distinct:
The `DISTINCT` keyword removes duplicate rows from query results.
SELECT DISTINCT department FROM employees;
sql.sql like:
The `LIKE` operator searches for patterns in text columns using wildcards (`%` and `_`).
SELECT * FROM users WHERE name LIKE 'Al%';
sql.sql in:
The `IN` operator checks if a value exists in a list of values.
SELECT * FROM users WHERE id IN (1, 2, 3);
sql.sql between:
The `BETWEEN` operator selects values within a given range (inclusive).
SELECT * FROM users WHERE age BETWEEN 25 AND 35;
sql.sql having:
The `HAVING` clause filters groups after `GROUP BY` based on aggregate conditions.
SELECT department, COUNT(*) FROM employees GROUP BY department HAVING COUNT(*) > 5;
sql.sql subquery:
A subquery is a query nested inside another query, useful for complex filtering.
SELECT * FROM users WHERE id IN (SELECT user_id FROM orders);
sql.sql index:
An `INDEX` improves query performance by creating a data structure that enables faster lookups.
CREATE INDEX idx_email ON users(email);
sql.sql union:
The `UNION` operator combines results from multiple `SELECT` statements, removing duplicates.
SELECT name FROM users UNION SELECT name FROM customers;
sql.sql union all:
The `UNION ALL` operator combines results from multiple queries, keeping duplicates.
SELECT name FROM users UNION ALL SELECT name FROM customers;
sql.sql case:
The `CASE` statement allows conditional logic within SQL queries.
SELECT name, CASE WHEN age >= 18 THEN 'Adult' ELSE 'Minor' END FROM users;
sql.sql views:
A `VIEW` is a virtual table based on a query result, useful for simplifying complex queries.
CREATE VIEW adult_users AS SELECT * FROM users WHERE age >= 18;
sql.sql primary key:
A `PRIMARY KEY` constraint uniquely identifies each record in a table.
CREATE TABLE users (
  id INT PRIMARY KEY,
  name VARCHAR(100)
);
sql.sql foreign key:
A `FOREIGN KEY` constraint links a column to a primary key in another table.
CREATE TABLE orders (
  id INT PRIMARY KEY,
  user_id INT,
  FOREIGN KEY (user_id) REFERENCES users(id)
);
sql.sql unique:
The `UNIQUE` constraint ensures all values in a column are unique.
CREATE TABLE users (
  id INT PRIMARY KEY,
  email VARCHAR(100) UNIQUE
);
sql.sql not null:
The `NOT NULL` constraint ensures a column cannot have NULL values.
CREATE TABLE users (
  id INT PRIMARY KEY,
  name VARCHAR(100) NOT NULL
);
sql.sql default:
The `DEFAULT` keyword assigns a default value to a column.
CREATE TABLE users (
  id INT PRIMARY KEY,
  status VARCHAR(50) DEFAULT 'active'
);
sql.sql check:
The `CHECK` constraint limits the values that can be inserted into a column.
CREATE TABLE users (
  id INT PRIMARY KEY,
  age INT CHECK (age >= 18)
);
sql.sql cross join:
The `CROSS JOIN` returns the Cartesian product of two tables.
SELECT * FROM colors CROSS JOIN sizes;
sql.sql self join:
A `SELF JOIN` joins a table to itself to compare rows within the same table.
SELECT a.name, b.name FROM users a
JOIN users b ON a.manager_id = b.id;
sql.sql window functions:
Window functions perform calculations across a range of rows related to the current row.
SELECT name, salary, AVG(salary) OVER (PARTITION BY department) FROM employees;
sql.sql cte:
A `Common Table Expression (CTE)` is a temporary named result set used within a query.
WITH cte AS (SELECT * FROM users WHERE age > 30)
SELECT * FROM cte;

java.java final: The final keyword prevents modification of variables, methods, or classes.
java.java final variable:

Packages organize classes into directories, preventing naming conflicts.
package com.example.app;
public class MyClass { }
java.java import:
The import statement brings classes from packages into the current file.
import java.util.ArrayList;
import java.util.*;
java.java serialization: Serialization converts objects into byte streams using Serializable interface.
java.java lambda:
Lambda expressions provide concise syntax for implementing functional interfaces.
List nums = Arrays.asList(1, 2, 3);
nums.forEach(n -> System.out.println(n));

from pyspark.sql import SparkSession
spark = SparkSession.builder \

    .getOrCreate()

rdd2 = spark.sparkContext.textFile('path/to/file.txt')

df = spark.createDataFrame(
    [('Alice', 25), ('Bob', 30)],
    ['name', 'age']
)

df.createOrReplaceTempView('people')
result = spark.sql('SELECT * FROM people WHERE age > 25')

Read CSV files into DataFrames using `spark.read.csv()`.
df = spark.read.csv('path/to/file.csv', header=True, inferSchema=True)
pyspark.pyspark read json:
Read JSON files into DataFrames using `spark.read.json()`.
df = spark.read.json('path/to/file.json')

Read Parquet files (columnar format) using `spark.read.parquet()`.
df = spark.read.parquet('path/to/file.parquet')

Define or inspect DataFrame schema (column names and types).
schema = df.schema
print(df.schema)
df.printSchema()

from pyspark.sql.types import StructType, StructField, StringType, IntegerType

    StructField('name', StringType(), True),

])
pyspark.pyspark select:
Select specific columns from a DataFrame.

df.select(df['name'], df['age'])
df.select(col('name'), col('age'))
pyspark.pyspark filter where:
Filter rows based on conditions using `filter()` or `where()`.

Add or modify columns using `withColumn()`.

df.withColumn('name_upper', upper(df['name']))

Remove columns from a DataFrame using `drop()`.
df.drop('column_name')
df.drop('col1', 'col2')
pyspark.pyspark groupby:
Group data by columns and apply aggregations.
df.groupBy('category').count()
df.groupBy('category').agg({'salary': 'sum', 'age': 'avg'})

from pyspark.sql.functions import sum, avg, max, min
df.agg(sum('salary'), avg('age'), max('salary'))

df1.join(df2, on='id')

df1.join(df2, on='id', how='left')

df1.intersect(df2)
